Revival or Just Plain Reboot?

By Martha Pollard

And Just Like That... Carrie Bradshaw, Charlotte, and Miranda are back in the city- leaving a Samantha-shaped hole in our hearts.

By Kyle Boulton

Sophia Ash excavates the bloody core of Robert Eggers' unrelenting blockbuster

By Kyle Boulton

Camila HernÃ¡ndez explores the theatrical hues of AlmodÃ³var's 1988 dark comedy

Revival or Just Plain Reboot?

By Martha Pollard

And Just Like That... Carrie Bradshaw, Charlotte, and Miranda are back in the city- leaving a Samantha-shaped hole in our hearts.

The Batman: A Gritty Take on the Caped Crusaderâ€™s Story

By Kyle Boulton

Michael Athey looks at Pattinsonâ€™s performance and the dark aesthetic of the new Batman film

Review: The Northman

By Kyle Boulton

Sophia Ash excavates the bloody core of Robert Eggers' unrelenting blockbuster

Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader

With Fox taking the reigns from Disney in the production of this latest adventure in Narnia, and with a new director on board in Michael Apted, this third instalment in the Chronicles of Narnia franchise finds itself in new company.

The Tourist

The basic premise of <em>The Tourist</em> sees Johnny Depp's titular holiday-maker lured into a trap of mistaken identity by Angelina Jolie's siren temptress

Neill Blomkamp: Redefining the Viral?

This video, directed by Neill Blomkamp - the man behind last year's groundbreaking sci-fi film <em>District 9</em> - was in a recent iPad edition of <em>WIRED</em> magazine. It's just over a minute long, and features two seemingly normal guys stumbling across what looks like the corpse of an alien, or at the very least a mutated creature of some description

Megamind

Halfway through its opening scene, as a blue alien baby is placed in a capsule ship to escape a dying planet, many people watching <em>Megamind</em> might think 'hang on... isn't this the plot of Superman?'

The Warrior's Way

So, this is a curiosity - a debut feature from director/screenwriter Sngmoo Lee with one tiny setting for most of its 100 minutes, with strong leads in a curious yet compelling cast, and a plot that can't decide whether it's a Western or a story about Eastern warrior values

Curzon launch first ever 'on demand' film service

With rapid advances in technology cinema has been under threat. Gareth Davies reports on Curzon Cinema's new venture, allowing you to watch new releases online

British Independent Film Awards

With the BIFAs announced, Mia de Graaf looks at its effect on the bigger award ceremonies, and what it means for UK film

London Boulevard

<em>London Boulevard</em> is a film that could have fallen down on any number of levels. Keira Knightley, the leading lady, is an actress who tends to polarise critics; it's the first job in the director's chair for William Monahan; Ray Winstone's in it, and he has a tendency to be plain disgusting (I mean, look at his face); and Colin Farrell's demonstrated his poor Laandan accent before

David Lynch launches musical career

David Lynch has always been eager to make the point that his exploits in film were a natural progression from his career as a visual artist. Lynch's newest venture, however, leads him into territories previously unexplored by the director

Unstoppable

Capitalising upon the success of Man on Fire, Deja Vu, and the recent remake of Taking of Pelham 123, director Tony Scott teams up once again with Denzel Washington, in this all American action-thriller

Skyline

The ever shifting currents of cinema have, of late, been moving into extraterrestrial territories. In the upcoming months we will be treated to the likes of <em>Battle: Los Angeles</em>, <em>Monsters</em> and <em>Paul</em>. So how does <em>Skyline</em> fare as one of the initial waves of such invasion narrative?

Top 5 Movie Assassins

To celebrate the release of Machete and The American, we explore cinema's five most formidable hitmen

Leeds Film Festival 2010

Gareth Davies & Michael Allard check out the selection on at the international film scene in Leeds this year

The American

It's marketed as an action-thriller, but it's not; for a film about an assassin on his last job, there's surprisingly little action. Most of the suspenseful sequences reach an underwhelming conclusion, and the traditional American firing range is replaced with a picturesque forest clearing in Italy

Machete

Unless you have accidentally stumbled into the wrong screen, it is more than likely that you know what you're getting when you step into <em>Machete</em>

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1

It's never good when you emerge from a cinema thinking "is that it?" Of course, with <em>Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1</em>, this was sort-of inevitable; any reader of the final book knows that there isn't a comfortable cut-off point around the middle, and as such the ending of this film tries its hardest to find a cliff-hanger, but ultimately comes up short

Due Date

First, director Todd Phillips made a name for himself with <em>Road Trip</em>. Then, following a decade-long detour by way of the Frat Pack, he made <em>The Hangover</em>, a film which made a lot of people laugh, particularly at the revelatory comic persona of Zach Galifianakis, and also made a huge profit

My Afternoons with Margueritte

Saccharine, cloying, nauseating, are just a few of the disparaging phrases which come to mind when attempting to describe Jean Becker's newest venture

Another Year

Mike Leigh's work in film for the past twenty years constitutes a significant oeuvre, and for those who argue that his most recent work is tied a little too strongly to either period drama (<em>Vera Drake</em>, <em>Topsy-Turvy</em>) or a cinema of unvarying mood (<em>All or Nothing</em>, <em>Happy-Go-Lucky</em>), they'll find that <em>Another Year</em> is a rich masterpiece - like <em>Secrets & Lies</em>, it's a great introduction to what Leigh does best

Let Me In

Remakes are risky business in pretty much any context. Occasionally, they end up being better than their source material, a perfect example being Terry Gilliam's borrowing of the themes and style of <em>La Jetee</em> to create <em>Twelve Monkeys</em>, a veritable masterpiece of modern cinema

Burke and Hare

John Landis is perhaps best known for formidable cult classics <em>The Blues Brothers</em>, and <em>An American Werewolf in London</em>, as well as a stream of commercial movies in the seventies and eighties. Burke and Hare, however, is the first film he has directed in twelve years. He seems to have gotten a little rusty...

The Kids Are All Right

I'm not surprised that there's already Oscar buzz surrounding this film. Annette Bening and Julianne Moore create some stunning moments, and both of them might easily be in the running for a couple of gongs come awards season

Saw 3D

Rarely is a sequel better than the original film - but a sixth sequel? Well, let's just say it would have to be superb, and <em>Saw 3D</em> (chronologically, <em>Saw VII</em>) is anything but

Africa United

I promised myself I wouldn't call <em>Africa United</em> - the first feature-length film from director Debs Gardner-Paterson, starring a cast of relative unknowns - the "African <em>Slumdog Millionaire</em>"

Red

In between the releases of heavy literary adaptations <em>The Last Station</em> and <em>The Tempest</em>, Dame Helen Mirren has found herself firing machine guns, sniper rifles and rocket launchers in <em>Red</em>. The value of seeing Queen Elizabeth II put on a menacing expression amidst explosions and shoot-outs manages to be more than just novelty

The Social Network

If asked to describe David Fincher's directorial style, one word that constantly springs to mind is ambitious. Never one to shy away from a challenging storyline, here he tries his hand at dissecting the petty playground politics of Facebook's founders and the subsequent struggle for power in <em>The Social Network</em>

Despicable Me

Let's get this out of the way: I cried at this film. That's not saying much, admittedly, considering you're reading the words of someone who cried at <em>Cool Runnings</em>, but then that same person is one of the few who believes that <em>Cool Runnings</em> is a masterpiece of modern cinema

Come and See (1985)

Critically acclaimed upon its release, and clocking over 25 million admissions in the Soviet Union alone, <em>Come and See</em> is the tale of a child soldier, Florya, and his fight for survival in Nazi occupied Belaru

Temptation and Taqwacores at this year's London Film Festival

Terms at York start late, but not quite late enough to spend a while at the country's biggest film festival, which finishes in a few days time

Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps

Like <em>Platoon</em> that was released the year before it, I like Oliver Stone's <em>Wall Street </em>not just for its political and social relevance, but because of its enjoyable simplicity

Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader

With Fox taking the reigns from Disney in the production of this latest adventure in Narnia, and with a new director on board in Michael Apted, this third instalment in the Chronicles of Narnia franchise finds itself in new company.
